description.p: A crackling white bolt of lightning sears into the ground and a thundering blast of superheated air tosses a gang of goblins to the ground. Flashing out of the space between sparks, a single ancient elf strides forth with ozone boiling out of his eyes.
Flowing and weaving through the waves, a goliath scoops downwards through the water with powerful strokes. Fish of a dozen colors and ancient blooming strands of sea kelp dance all around her.

Flickering flames leap and dance from a tabaxi trader’s golden claws, casting glimmering reflections on the eyes of a dozen fascinated strangers as he regales them with tales of his wares, hard won from the Elemental Plane of Fire.

The world is composed of four elements. Earth, Air, Fire, and Water. Their constant intermingling, coexistence, and conflict generates the fundamental energy of existence and life. An Elementalist embraces this energy, bonding intimately with the very fabric of the world, twisting and shaping earth, sea, sun and sky to their will.

Elementalists spend their time in constant meditation and learning, but not from scrolls or dusty tomes. The elements are best understood in their rawest form, as they appear in nature. An Elementalist might spend a lifetime absorbed in the way water tumbles over a great fall, or travel to a far-off volcano in search of its fiery secrets. These pursuits often bring them to wild frontiers, where the elements are still untamed by civilization. Many become wanderers and hermits, endlessly seeking new manifestations of elemental energy in ever more remote bastions of wilderness.

No element can stand alone without the others. The world is defined by the balance of all four elements, and no-one knows the importance of their interplay better than an Elementalist. When one element predominates over the other, the wielder of that element can become dangerously skewed. An inexperienced fire mage may find themselves developing an awful temper, while one that wields the power of freezing ice too readily may lose joy and vigor, sinking into a cold depression.

Some masters choose to embrace this imbalance, taking advantage of a certain element’s most powerful aspects and checking the downsides with rigorous discipline. Others cultivate an equal dominion over all the elements, dancing from one to the next with perfect grace.

Elementalists are defined by their experience of the world around them. Looking upon a grazing horse, one might feel the presence of the earth in its hard hooves and the grass it plucks from the ground to sustain itself. Another might see its steaming breath, and the flash of flaming pride in its eyes. The breeze through its mane might conjure the memory of freedom as it gallops across rolling hills chasing the wind, or the flowing ripples of its limbs might recall the beating tide of life that sustains all creatures. How does your character experience the elements?
You can make an Elementalist quickly by following these suggestions. First, Wisdom should be your highest ability score, followed by Constitution or Dexterity. Second, choose the hermit background.
As an elementalist, you gain the following class features.

ul.li: Hit Points at 1st Level: 6 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d6 (or 4) + your Constitution modifier per elementalist level after 1st
Skills: Choose two from Arcana, History, Insight, Investigation, Medicine, Nature, Perception, and Survival.

description.p: You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

ul.li: (a) any simple weapon or (b) a shortsword
(a) a scholar’s pack or (b) an explorer’s pack
a dagger, a quarterstaff, and an elemental focus

description.p: At 1st level, you have learned to align your mind and body with a particular element, bringing that element’s magic to the forefront of your awareness. You have four separate entwinement dice which represent the four elements: 1d6 for Fire, 1d8 for Water, 1d10 for Air, and 1d12 for Earth. As a bonus action, you may spend any one of those dice to become entwined with the corresponding element.

Being entwined with an element is a lasting condition. Your entwinement with an element ends when you entwine with a different element. When you entwine with a new element, you also regain one expended entwinement die of your choice. You may not choose to regain the die of either the element you are leaving or the element you are entering entwinement with.
Whenever you entwine with a new element, you may produce an instant magical effect related to that element:

Fire: Searing Nova: Flames surge out from you. Deal (1d6) fire damage to yourself. Neither resistance nor immunity can reduce the damage you take. All other creatures within 10 feet of you are dealt the same damage you dealt to yourself.

Water: Soothing Mist: A puff of cool, soothing mist bursts out from you, settling over each creature within 10 feet of you. When you use a spell to restore hit points to a creature shrouded by this mist, that creature regains (1d8) bonus hit points and the mist around it fades away. This mist fades from all affected creatures at the end of your next turn.

Air: Electric Discharge: A lightning bolt flashes down, striking at a single creature you can see within 60 feet of you. That creature must make a Dexterity saving throw against your spell save DC, taking (1d10) lightning damage on a failure or avoiding the damage entirely on a success.

Earth: Armor of Earth: Pebbles and stones rise around you, granting you a protective barrier. When you are hit by an attack while entwined with Earth you may reduce the damage you take by (1d12). You have one use of this feature and regain all uses when you entwine with Earth.

The magnitude ( ) of each effect is increased by an additional corresponding entwinement die when you achieve your 5th, 11th, and 17th levels in this class. The radii of Searing Nova and Soothing Mist are increased by 5 feet and the range of Electric Discharge is increased by 30 feet when you achieve your 11th Elementalist level, and again at 17th level.

sheet.description: Your have four entwinement dice: 1d6 - Fire. 1d8 - Water. 1d10 - Air. 1d12 - Earth. You expend one of your entwinement dice to become entwined with the corresponding element. Your entwinement ends when you entwine with a new element. Whenever you entwine with a new element, you may produce an instant magical effect.

description.p: An Elementalist is capable of wielding magic at 1st level to exert their mastery over the base components of the world. Elemental magic is volatile and unique, governed by special rules described in this section. See chapter 10 in the PHB for the general rules of spellcasting and page 7 of this resource for the Elementalist spell list.

At 1st level, you know all the cantrips and 1st level spells on the Elementalist spell list. When you first gain a spell slot of a certain spell level, you also learn all the Elementalist spells of that spell level.
You must have a spell prepared to cast it, and you prepare spells by entwining with elements using the Elemental Entwinement feature as follows:

While you are entwined with an element, you have all of the spells you know from that element’s section of the Elementalist spell list prepared to cast, and you lose access to any others. While you are not entwined with an element, you do not have any spells of that element prepared.
You may maintain your concentration on a spell even if you lose access to it by entwining with a different element.

Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for your Elementalist spells, as their power derives from your awareness of and connection with the elements and their properties. You use your Wisdom whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Wisdom modifier when setting the saving throw DC for an Elementalist spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.
Spell save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier
Spell attack modifier = your proficiency bonus + your Wisdom modifier

You can use an elemental focus as your spellcasting focus for your Elementalist spells. An elemental focus is a small token or artifact which helps an Elementalist deepen their bond with elements and the physical world. A glowing coal held at the end of a staff, a pendent vial filled with everfrozen ice, or a dark gem hewn from the heart of a forgotten cave may all serve as elemental foci.
You can cast an Elementalist spell as a ritual if that spell has the ritual tag and you have the spell prepared.

sheet.description: When you entwine with an element, you gain access to all the spells for that element.

description.p: An elemental focus is a small token or artifact which helps an Elementalist deepen their bond with elements and the physical world. A glowing coal held at the end of a staff, a pendent vial filled with everfrozen ice, or a dark gem hewn from the heart of a forgotten cave may all serve as elemental foci.

As an Elementalist deepens their connection with the bare aspects of the natural world, they may take on some of the signature characteristics of the four elements. These traits are reflected in an Elementalist’s personality, thoughts, demeanor, and the magic they wield. At 2nd level, you are an Initiate in the ways of elemental magic. You may choose any Initiate tier trait. At 5th level you will become an Adept, at 9th level you will become a Master, and at 14th level you will become a Grandmaster. You can choose any trait at each tier, whether of a consistent theme with or differing completely from the traits you selected previously.

When you reach 2nd level you may select one Initiate tier trait to learn. At 5th level you may select one trait of Adept tier or lower learn. At 9th level you may select on trait of Master tier or lower to learn. At 14th level you may select one trait of Grandmaster tier or lower to learn.

At the end of a long rest, you can replace any one trait you have with a different one that is available to you. You cannot have traits from a certain tier unless you have at least 1 trait from each lower tier. For example, at level 5 you can have 1 Initiate trait and 1 Adept trait or 2 Initiate traits and no Adept traits, but you may not have 2 Adept traits with no Initiate traits.

Also at 2nd level, your bond to the elements manifests visibly. When you are entwined with an element, a minor manifestation of that element springs up around your body and follows you. For example, flames might flicker out of your eyes, or small crystals may wrap around your wrists like bracelets. Icy mist could swirl in your path, or a gentle breeze loft through your hair. The precise nature of this effect is up to your conscious choice and you can suppress this occurrence at your will.

sheet.description: When you are entwined with an element, a minor manifestation of that element springs up around your body and follows you.

description.p: At 3rd level, when you entwine with an element your bond with it bolsters your physical form. You gain certain resistances when entwined:
Fire: Resistance to Fire damage.
Water: Resistance to Cold damage.
Air: Resistance to Lightning damage.
Earth: Resistance to Bludgeoning damage.

sheet.description: You gain certain resistances when entwined: Fire: Fire damage. Water: Cold damage. Air: Lightning damage. Earth: Bludgeoning damage.

description.p: When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 15th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

The moment of entwinement is an instant of shifting, unformed potential. By 6th level you have learned to take advantage of this moment to reshape the elements as you desire. If you cast a spell immediately after entwining with a new element, then you may replace the damage type of that cast with the damage type of another spell you know, from either the previous element or the new one.

sheet.description: If you cast a spell immediately after entwining with a new element, then you may replace the damage type of that cast with the damage type of another spell you know, from either the previous element or the new one.

description.p: Upon reaching 18th level, you have strengthened your bond with the elements to the point that you can channel catastrophic power. When you entwine with an element, you may choose to overload yourself instead of losing your previous entwinement. For the next hour your existing entwinements are not ended by entwining with a new element, you may activate any of Elemental Entwinement’s magical effects as a bonus action without entwining, and you may use Chaotic Entwinement at any time, selecting from the damage types of any spell you have prepared. Channeling the elements this way takes a terrible toll, and you cannot easily close yourself to this power. You cannot leave this state until it ends. At the end of the hour you gain one level of exhaustion and end all your entwinements, regaining all spent entwinement dice.

sheet.description: When you entwine with an element, for the next hour your existing entwinements are not ended, and you may use Chaotic Entwinement at any time, selecting from the damage types of any spell you have prepared. You cannot leave this state until it ends. At the end of the hour you gain one level of exhaustion and end all your entwinements, regaining all spent entwinement dice.

When you entwine with an element, for the next hour your existing entwinements are not ended, and you may use Chaotic Entwinement at any time, selecting from the damage types of any spell you have prepared. You cannot leave this state until it ends.

description.p: At 20th level, you are an unsurpassed grandmaster of the elements. Channeling the four elements comes as easily to you as breathing, and the scale of your powers can only be described as cataclysmic. Elemental Overload no longer exhausts you. When you are entwined with all four elements, you may expend any number of spell slots to trigger some monumental elemental event. Work with your DM to determine an appropriate contextual occurrence. The scale of this event should depend on the number of slots expended. An Elementalist unleashing all their power can accomplish feats like raising a river to flood, triggering a volcanic eruption, or turning a mountain into a valley.

sheet.description: When you are entwined with all four elements, you may expend any number of spell slots to trigger some monumental elemental event.

description.p: At the start of your turn, you may choose to end all your entwinements and regain all expended entwinement dice. After you use this feature, you can’t do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

sheet.description: At the start of your turn, you may choose to end all your entwinements and regain all expended entwinement dice.

description.p: Whenever one of your spells deals fire damage to two or more creatures at the same time you may take a reaction to activate your Searing Nova effect, as if you had entwined with Fire (see the Elemental Entwinement feature).

sheet.description: Whenever one of your spells deals fire damage to two or more creatures at the same time you may take a reaction to activate your Searing Nova effect.

description.p: The maximum duration of your Soothing Mist is increased by one round. When a creature you can see would fail a saving throw or ability check while your Soothing Mist is clinging to them, you may take a reaction and expend a spell slot of any level to renew their vigor. The target creature may reroll the failed roll and you may grant them a 1d8 bonus to the new attempt. If the target creature makes use of this effect, it must use the result of the new roll and your Soothing Mist fades from it whether it passes or fails.

sheet.description: The maximum duration of your Soothing Mist is increased by one round. When a creature you can see would fail a saving throw or ability check while your Soothing Mist is clinging to them, you may take a reaction and expend a spell slot of any level to renew their vigor. The target creature may reroll the failed roll and you may grant them a 1d8 bonus to the new attempt.

description.p: Your speed increases by 10 feet. When you have a flying speed, that flying speed is increased by a further 10 feet. When you damage a creature with a spell or magical effect, you don’t provoke opportunity attacks from that creature for the rest of the turn.

sheet.description: When you damage a creature with a spell or magical effect, you don’t provoke opportunity attacks from that creature for the rest of the turn.

description.p: You gain an additional use of Armor of Earth. Whenever you entwine with Earth, you may touch one other willing creature to grant one further use of Armor of Earth to that creature. Other creatures granted uses of the Armor of Earth feature by this trait do not need to be entwined with Earth to benefit from them and lose those uses at the end of your next turn. You cannot grant a creature uses of Armor of Earth with this trait if it already has uses of Armor of Earth, or if it has the ability to grant itself uses of Armor of Earth.

sheet.description: Whenever you entwine with Earth, you may touch one other willing creature to grant one further use of Armor of Earth to that creature.

description.p: Your Swirling Elements feature grows more grandiose and impressive. You learn the mage hand cantrip and always have it prepared (regardless of entwinement). When you cast it, instead of creating a spectral hand you reach out with a minor, delicate component of your Swirling Elements, such as a tendril of water or a floating clump of pebbles.

sheet.description: When you cast mage hand, you reach out with a minor, delicate component of your Swirling Elements.

description.p: Whenever you take fire damage your blood is ignited until the end of your next turn. While the effect of this trait is active, whenever you are hit by a melee attack the attacker takes fire damage equal to your Elementalist level.

sheet.description: Whenever you take fire damage your blood is ignited until the end of your next turn. While the effect of this trait is active, whenever you are hit by a melee attack the attacker takes {{level:elementalist}} fire damage.

description.p: When you restore hit points to one or more creatures using a spell, if any of those targets are charmed, frightened, blinded, deafened, petrified, paralyzed, or stunned, you may choose of those creatures and end one of those effects on it. You may activate this trait when attempting to heal a creature even if that creature already has their maximum number of hit points.

sheet.description: When you restore hit points to one or more creatures using a spell, if any of those targets are charmed, frightened, blinded, deafened, petrified, paralyzed, or stunned, you may choose of those creatures and end one of those effects on it. You may activate this trait when attempting to heal a creature even if that creature already has their maximum number of hit points.

description.p: When a target fails the saving throw against your Electric Discharge, if that target is stunned, restrained, paralyzed, or petrified, they take an additional 1d10 lightning damage. At any time on your turn, if you are entwined with Air, you may take an action to produce an Electric Discharge.

sheet.description: When a target fails the saving throw against your Electric Discharge, if that target is stunned, restrained, paralyzed, or petrified, they take an additional 1d10 lightning damage. At any time on your turn, if you are entwined with Air, you may take an action to produce an Electric Discharge.

description.p: Whenever one of your spells or magical effects causes a creature to become restrained, paralyzed, stunned, pushed, pulled, prone, or petrified, you also blind that creature until the end of its next turn.

sheet.description: Whenever one of your spells or magical effects causes a creature to become restrained, paralyzed, stunned, pushed, pulled, prone, or petrified, you also blind that creature until the end of its next turn.

description.p: Immediately after using a bonus action to entwine with a new element, you may instantly cast a cantrip within the same bonus action, ignoring its normal casting time. Any damage dealt this way is halved. Casting a cantrip this way is considered casting a bonus action spell for the purpose of restrictions regarding bonus action spells (PHB pg.202).

sheet.description: Immediately after using a bonus action to entwine with a new element, you may instantly cast a cantrip within the same bonus action, ignoring its normal casting time. Any damage dealt this way is halved.

description.p: If you are reduced to 0 hit points by fire damage or take fire damage while at 0 hit points, you become immune to death and healing until the start of your next turn, at which time you immediately regain 8d6 hit points and become immune to fire damage until the end of the turn. After this trait activates, it can’t activate again until you finish a long rest.

sheet.description: If you are reduced to 0 hit points by fire damage or take fire damage while at 0 hit points, you become immune to death and healing until the start of your next turn, at which time you immediately regain 8d6 hit points and become immune to fire damage until the end of the turn.

description.p: When you restore hit points to one or more creatures using a spell, you may take a reaction to choose one of those targets and have your water magic explode out from their body. The target loses hit points equal to the number of hit points they regained. All other creatures within 10 feet of the target must pass a Dexterity saving throw against your spell-save DC or take cold damage equal to the number of hit points that the target lost, be pushed 10 feet directly away from the target, and have their speed set to 0 until the start of your next turn.

sheet.description: When you restore hit points to one or more creatures using a spell, you may take a reaction to choose one of those targets and have your water magic explode out from their body. The target loses hit points equal to the number of hit points they regained. All other creatures within 10 feet of the target must pass a Dexterity saving throw against your spell-save DC or take cold damage equal to the number of hit points that the target lost, be pushed 10 feet directly away from the target, and have their speed set to 0 until the start of your next turn.

description.p: If you cast gaseous form targeting only yourself, you may cast it without any components. While you are under the effects of the Gaseous Form or Wind Walk spells, you gain 50 feet of bonus flying speed, you are invisible, and you become immune to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage, and the restrained and grappled conditions.

sheet.description: If you cast gaseous form targeting only yourself, you may cast it without any components. While you are under the effects of the Gaseous Form or Wind Walk spells, you gain 50 feet of bonus flying speed, you are invisible, and you become immune to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage, and the restrained and grappled conditions.

description.p: You gain an additional use of Armor of Earth. Uses of Armor of Earth that you grant to yourself or other creatures become reactive to assault. When one such use successfully reduces the damage of a melee attack to 0, the attacker is knocked prone.

sheet.description: Uses of Armor of Earth that you grant to yourself or other creatures become reactive to assault. When one such use successfully reduces the damage of a melee attack to 0, the attacker is knocked prone.

description.p: You learn the conjure elemental spell, always have it prepared, and maintain control of it without concentrating, but for you its casting time is 1 hour, its duration is 24 hours, and to successfully cast it at any spell level you must expend two spell slots of that level or higher. If you conjure a new elemental while you control another, the previous one disappears instantly.

sheet.description: When you cast conjure elemental, you maintain control without concentration, but for you its casting time is 1 hour, its duration is 24 hours, and to successfully cast it at any spell level you must expend two spell slots of that level or higher.

description.p: When a spell you cast ends, if it had a duration longer than instantaneous and dealt fire damage to a creature or object, it leaves behind a 3rd level lava font. The lava condenses from the flames of the dying spell, at a target location you choose on the ground within the previous spell’s area.

sheet.description: When a spell you cast ends, if it had a duration longer than instantaneous and dealt fire damage to a creature or object, it leaves behind a 3rd level lava font. The lava condenses from the flames of the dying spell, at a target location you choose on the ground within the previous spell’s area.

description.p: Creatures shrouded by your Soothing Mist gain a 1d8 bonus to attack rolls and receive the benefit of any resistances you have due to your Embrace the Elements feature. At any time on your turn, no matter your current entwinement, you may expend a spell slot of any level as a bonus action to produce your Soothing Mist effect, as if you had entwined with Water.

sheet.description: Creatures shrouded by your Soothing Mist gain a 1d8 bonus to attack rolls and receive the benefit of any resistances you have due to your Embrace the Elements feature. At any time on your turn, no matter your current entwinement, you may expend a spell slot of any level as a bonus action to produce your Soothing Mist effect, as if you had entwined with Water.

description.p: You gain a flying speed of 60 feet and the Hover property. While flying, you have advantage on Dexterity saving throws and your movement is silent.

sheet.description: You can hover. While flying, you have advantage on Dexterity saving throws and your movement is silent.

description.p: When you would fail a saving throw while entwined with Earth you may take a reaction to ignore that failure and pass instead. You can use this feature once, and you regain the ability to do so when you entwine with Earth again.

sheet.description: When you would fail a saving throw while entwined with Earth you may take a reaction to ignore that failure and pass instead. You can use this feature once, and you regain the ability to do so when you entwine with Earth again.

description.p: Choose two points you can see within range that have only unoccupied space between them. A thin electric arc leaps through the air, suspending itself between the two target points. While it persists, it gives off a subtly audible crackle and sheds dim light across a 5-foot radius around itself. If an object or creature contacts the arc, they must make a Constitution saving throw. They suffer 2d10 lightning damage and become stunned until the end of their next turn if they fail or take half the damage and are not stunned if they pass. Pass or fail, the arc then snaps out of existence with a loud thunderclap audible from as far away as 300 feet. If the duration expires before the trap is triggered, it fizzles away silently, leaving no trace. If you cast this spell again while an arc trap you cast previously persists, the previous trap fizzles away instantly.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage is increased by 1d10 for each slot level above 1st.

Manifest searing jets of flame which push you up to 30 feet in any direction you choose, even vertically. This movement doesn’t trigger opportunity attacks. If this movement pushes you through space occupied by another creature, they must make a Dexterity saving throw or suffer 2d6 fire damage. If there is insufficient unoccupied space for you at the end of the movement, you stop early in the furthest unoccupied space along the line. At the end of your movement the propelling flames flare out and explode. All creatures in a 10-foot radius spherical area around you besides yourself must make a Dexterity saving throw, suffering 2d6 fire damage on a failure or half as much if they pass.

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, for each slot level above 2nd, the damage of the movement and the final explosion are both increased by 1d6 and the movement range is increased by 10 feet.

A wave of refreshing water splashes out from you, healing wounds and washing away filth. All creatures in a 10-foot radius sphere centered on yourself regain hit points equal to 1d8 + your spellcasting modifier. If any creatures in the area are poisoned or diseased, this spell cures one of those ailments on each of those creatures (their choice). This spell does not restore hit points to undead or constructs.

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, for each slot level above 2nd, the radius is increased by 5 feet and it cures an additional ailment on each affected creature.

An earthen blast launches you into the air along an arcing trajectory, which you may make up to 30 feet high and 15 feet long horizontally. This movement doesn’t trigger opportunity attacks. If you are not standing on a solid surface when you cast this spell, you forgo the movement portion of this spell. The next time you touch the ground this turn, if you fell at least 10 feet immediately prior, you land with cratering force. You don’t take fall damage from this impact, and all other creatures on the ground within 5 feet of you must then make a Strength saving throw. Creatures that fail the saving throw take 2d12 bludgeoning damage and are pushed 10 feet directly away from you. Creatures that pass take only half the damage and are not pushed. The ground within 5 feet of you becomes difficult terrain which lasts until cleared. Each 5-foot-square portion of the area requires at least 1 minute to clear by hand.

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, for each slot level above 2nd, the damage is increased by 1d12 and the maximum height of the arc is increased by 30 feet.

When you deal lightning damage to one or more creatures or objects using a spell or magical effect, you may take a reaction to cast this spell. Teleport to an unoccupied location within 5 feet of one of those creatures or objects, and this spell deals 2d10 lightning damage to that target. If you can see any of the area around your target you may choose a destination inside that area, but if you cannot then the destination is determined randomly from the available area. If no such location is available, then you fail to teleport and you take this spell’s lightning damage.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the damage is increased by 1d10 for each slot level above 2nd.

Call forth the roiling heat of the earth to create a magical gout of lava. Choose a point on the ground within range, and lava surges up to the surface. A volume of lava sufficient to occupy the base of a five-foot cube to one-foot depth flows out as a thick liquid, remaining in a single location if the ground is flat or flowing in a cohesive globule at a rate of up to 5 feet per round on a slope. A creature that walks across the lava takes 6d6 fire damage for every five feet of lava it crosses, and if a creature ends its turn on the lava it takes 12d6 fire damage. Lava is unimaginably hot and heavy. This volume of molten rock weighs 5000 pounds. It ignites flammable objects and structures near it and will slowly melt stone and metal it remains in contact with. This lava magically cools into a smooth, glassy black stone when this spell ends.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, for each slot level above 3rd, another identical volume of lava is created in an adjacent location you choose.

Call on a massive upswelling of enchanted water to surge up from a point you choose on the ground within range. The water mounds up into a 15-foot high, 15-foot radius hemi-spherical dome. Creatures in the area are rejuvenated by the rising water, regaining hit points equal to 2d8 + your spellcasting modifier. The mass of water then collapses downwards, washing outwards along the ground to extinguish unprotected flames and carry away loose objects. Creatures in the area must pass a Strength saving throw or be knocked prone and pushed 15 feet directly away from the origin. A creature may freely choose to fail this saving throw, opting to let themselves be carried by the water and pushed twice as far. If the movement of a creature pushed by this spell is interrupted by a hard surface or obstacle, that creature takes 2d8 bludgeoning damage from the collision. This spell does not restore hit points to undead or constructs.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the healing is increased by 1d8 for each slot level above 3rd.

setters.set: a bucket of water drawn from a well

description.p: Tear the ground in a line in front of yourself into jagged peaks that clasp at foes. Send a powerful shock wave out from yourself, which is 10 feet wide and travels rapidly along the ground for 120 feet. The ground traversed by the wave buckles and tears apart, becoming difficult terrain which lasts until cleared. Each 5-foot-square portion of the area requires at least 1 minute to clear by hand. Creatures in the area when this spell is cast must make a Dexterity saving throw. Those that fail are struck by the shock wave, knocked prone, restrained, and take 2d12 bludgeoning damage. Creatures that pass take half the damage and are neither knocked prone nor restrained. A restrained target can use its action to make a Strength check against your spell save DC. On a success, the target shatters the stones pinning it down and is no longer restrained.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 5th level or higher, for each slot level above 4th, the damage increases by 1d12 and the width of the wave increases by 5 feet.

Fine sand swirls out from you, churning through the air throughout a cylindrical area of 30-foot radius and 80-foot height. The origin of the storm is your location, and if you are elevated in the air for any reason the storm also extends downwards from you towards the ground, for a distance up to its maximum height. The storm spreads around corners. The area is heavily obscured, and creatures within have disadvantage on perception checks made using hearing or smell. Unprotected air-breathing creatures within the area must hold their breath or begin to suffocate. A creature attempting to fly in the area must spend five feet of movement for each foot it moves. When a creature ends its turn in the area it takes 3d4 slashing and 3d4 piercing damage. The swirling area of the storm does not include a central eye, which is a 10-foot radius cylinder of the same height as the storm, also centered on you. The eye of the storm is perfectly calm, and not subject to any of the effects of this spell. Both the storm and the eye move with you.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 6th level or higher, the exterior radius and height increase by 20 feet for each slot level above 5th.

Ignite yourself, turning your body to flame. Deal 20d6 fire damage to yourself as you fuel a searing geyser of flame. Neither resistance nor immunity can reduce the damage you take. The torrent of flame fills a 15-foot radius, 600-foot-height cylinder rising from your body, flaring upwards into the sky. All other creatures in the area must make a Dexterity saving throw. Creatures that fail take the same damage you dealt to yourself. Creatures that pass are pushed 15 feet directly away from you. If they end this movement outside the area of the flames, they take only half the damage. If they end this movement within the area of the flame, they take the full damage. The pillar of flame ignites objects and burns clean through flammable obstacles, such as wooden structures or shingle roofs. If the damage of this spell reduces you to 0 hit points your unconscious body remains wreathed in fire and you regain 1 hit point at the start of your next turn, unless you die before that can occur.
At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 7th level or higher, the damage increases by 2d6 for each slot level above 6th.
